25 years ago we lived in India for a few years. So Pettah in 2025 is an Indian provincial town in the 200s... Nothing new was found for themselves. The anchor place - the floating market - is frankly dying. It's not floating at all, just a concrete base in the middle of a dirty pond.
Hustling hub of retail business . Were the real Colombo starts. If you find Galle Green too dull then head to Pettah. Great for street food or anything else you may need

column8: There is no greater variety of attractions in Colombo.…
column11: The name of the area comes from the Sinhalese for "City outside the Fort". In the beginning, the whole city could fit into the Fort, and the British colonialists considered Pettah to be "black" areas where it was not worth poking a white man's nose. Everyone lives in Pettakh now. It is the shopping and transportation hub of Colombo. There is a railway station and a bus station here. The area itself is a large flea market, where they sell everything. Most of the tourist landmarks are also located here. The symbol of the area is the Khan Tower on Main Street. It is named after the initiator of the construction, a family of wealthy Parsis from Bombay. The Old Town Hall, where the City Council met for 50 years until 1925, is also here. By the way, there is now a corresponding museum in the Dutch period Town Hall. If the commercial part (for example, the Pettah floating market) is located in the south, then the sacred establishments, on the contrary, are in the north. It is the most beautiful mosque in Colombo- Jamul Alfar, the main Protestant church during the Dutch rule - Volvendaal (the name means Valley of Wolves) and the most important Hindu temple complex - old and new Kathiresan, dedicated to the god of war Skanda. There is no greater variety of attractions in Colombo.…

Very busy walkway with lots of shops and some hawkers lining up on the streets. It is crowded and very noisy as you would expect with so much going on. Shops selling just about everything. You will either love it or hate it and will want to get out quickly. It was the latter for us and we left the area.

column8: Authentic experience, somebody needs to open a cafe and souvenir stores to make it more tourist friendly
column11: So, this is an amazing market where you get the authentic experience of a mostly wholesale market.  it is not yet geared for tourists although all the elements are there. somebody just needs to open a few cafes and some souvenir stores.  to what it was, its huge.  electronics, fabrics, knick nacks, a few mosques/temples that were beautiful.

Pettah market was recommended to us by a hotel staff  for souvenirs gifts. This market place is very busy, noisy, and there is a red mosque there also. I wanted some batik sarongs and I found this wholesaler Rizwan Tex on 3rd Street and his prices was very reasonable compared  other outlets. The store  is small but very busy with a wide selection of different styles and colours.  I enjoyed the market and each road sells different items.  However, getting a Uber back to our hotel was a little tricky. You have to find a clear area where they can pick up you from, which we did near a Hindu Temple on one of the main roads. This place is not for everyone because it fast moving and congested with people and traffic , but I liked it.
Arab Quarter with shops in every street of every kind but nothing to do with the oriental bazaars. I drove by to see the Mosque and I didn't feel like getting off
We enjoyed a walk around this local market area and also saw the red mosque. Not particularly touristy but that was good for us. We bought some shirts and took in the bustle of the area.

The Pettah area is probably the most exhausting and chaotic part of Colombo…certainly in our 60 hours in the city we didn’t see anything else that even came close. We decided to stay in a quieter area, but Pettah is a place you have to visit, because the Floating Market, the Jami Ul-Alfar Mosque (which we never saw the inside of, as its visiting hours are restricted), and, of course, Fort Railway Station and the bus depot (including the express to the airport which costs just 300 rupees) are all nearby. A dizzying half-day in its crowded streets and alleys makes one appreciate the comparative quiet and leisurely pace of the mid-town area, where we spent two peaceful nights at the City Hotel Colombo-02.

Excellent place to meet wholesalers and distributors . went to buy fabrics and got excellent deals. you need to research and contact sources before going very crowded market with locals and hard to find a parking spot . better to have a driver
Sri Lankan market. The area is quite large. While visiting the Red Mosque and Hindu temples, it's a good idea to take a walk.
Very noisy too many people ,anarque to tourist, smell, I don't think I'll go back overall a little disappointing.

It's full of people, on foot, by car, in touk-touk... full of colors, local products. We find everything. There is the street of fishmongers, the street of fruit trees, the street of drug dealers, the street of spices, the street of jewelers etc... Very exotic

Our family visit to Pettah Market in Colombo was a fantastic experience! This bustling local market offers an incredible variety of items, from clothes, kitchenware, and shoes to jewelry, groceries, and fresh fruits. The vibrant atmosphere, friendly vendors, and the sheer diversity of products make it a must-visit destination for anyone in search of daily essentials or unique finds. Whether you’re looking for practical household items or just soaking in the local culture, Pettah Market has something for everyone. Highly recommended for an authentic Colombo shopping experience!

We arrived by train and went to this street market from the railway station. It was a bit shocking for me at first. Noise, heavy traffic, hot (35 degrees) and lots of different things. It was chaotic, but later we found a calmer part. I think it’s an interesting local experience and everything is cheaper than the hotel shops.
Pettah market is too crowded and one cannot visit with the family as the place is too crowded and nothing special we can find . It’s very similar like any other normal markets .
Interesting experience: pure chaos and just a lot of people. Very cheap goods, but a lot of it is just cheap junk.

I  visited this market several times while I was in Colombo.  I had cheap dinners at two restaurants here, also bought some fresh fruits and baked goods. There are lots to buy here: Jewelries, particularly gold, clothings, shoes, household items, items. Along the way from my hotel to this  market are wholesalers selling spices, rice, cooking oil, etc. Very chaotic here, but after my first day visiting, I became more proficientt crossing the very busy streets and bargaining with locals.

An actual street market, so expect entire streets selling single items or genres of item (we walked silks and ribbons street). Heads up this is not a touristy market like in southern Thailand, but an actual functioning market that people just go to in order to buy bulk necessities and materials for their businesses. It is crowded and smells of exhaust, and will not be for everyone, but if you want to see a real market this compares with some of the better ones, including even the famous bazaars at Kashgar or Istanbul.

This is an outdoor market selling pretty much everything from phone cases to  clothes. It’s like a maze with streets leading to streets and it seemed to be divided into sections with a clothing section, jewellery section etc. Pettah is massive,  absolutely jam packed with people and stalls, there are places to pick up a drink but we didn’t find anywhere we could sit to drink it. We went early morning and it wasn’t too bad but by midday it was very very busy and exceptionally hot.

column7: Ashby de la Zouch, United Kingdom
column11: To be honest, this may be the biggest market in Colombo but it doesn’t have that much to recommend it. Lively enough but most of the good are generic and low quality. The fruit and vegetable area was probably the most interesting.

Disgusting men who glare, whistle and make nasty comments. But this applies to all of Colombo unfortunately.. We came from midigama where everyone was super nice and kind to this and I can say that I will never come back to Colombo more than to the airport. DO NOT go here as a single girl..

This area has it all. It has plenty of hustle and bustle. Loads of vibrant colours from the food markets. Amazing smells of dried chilli and spices down some streets. Plenty of places to stop and grab a bite to eat or drink. Loved wandering around
We have walked ten kilometers in the hustle and bustle of sellers, markets, pedestrian and motorized traffic. Only happiness. There is a beautiful mosque and 3 Hindu temples. Exciting and essential.
It is busy market place. Wear comfortable shoes,  sun screen, hat or umbrella.  Many shops reasonable price. Don't forget to bargain.

Streets and more streets full of people, of products sold on the street, in stores. Fabrics, toys, fish, fruit, you can find everything. It is the haggling area par excellence. My advice is to start with a third of the price they ask you and you will end up buying for less than half. Sometimes you realize that you are haggling for 1 euro. There are also several buildings that are worth seeing even from the outside. One is the old town hall and the other is the mosque.

Pettah is hectic. A number of different streets make up Pettah and sell everything from fruit, lassi, clothing, watches (mostly fakes), phone covers, pots, pans. You name it. A great place to get lost and enjoy the real Colombo. It's safe and tourist friendly.

Firstly choose the day to visit wisely. Weekdays seemed to be less busier. Secondly, pre choose your route. The market is spread out like a maze, each street has never ending shops. On top of that, the roads are packed with vehicles especially tuk tuks. Watch where you are going! It can get quite hot and humid while walking around. There are numerous drink and snack shops where you can stop for a break. Be sure to visit the Red mosque and temples. If you want shopping, this is a cheap area to get some bargains.

English below Halusimme päästä perinteisen basaarin tunnelmaan ja ostamaan tuliaisia. Sen sijaan jouduimme keskelle kaaosta, jossa väkisin yritetään myydä ja sanaa ei ei ymmärretä. Turistit ovat kadonneet ja asiakkaista pulaa, joten tavara on pölyistä ja likaista ja hinnat taivaissa. Samoja tuotteita saa esim. pikkukylistä edullisemmin ja mukavammalla tavalla ostettuna. Very crowded dirty place, where sellers are trying their best and don't listening word no at all. Products are dirty and old because turists are away. Go small villages and buy same products from there in same price but much nicer people.

Offcourse it's heaven for Cheap stuff. You should go there especially if you love street shopping be it clothes, electronics, sweets, eateries etc. You don't have to buy, just walk around and your eyes will glitter automatically seeing all the stuff. Btw click pics at the very famous Red Mosque. It's beautiful. Have a sweet or two at Mumbai Sweets ( no idea why they named stores after Mumbai)

A really good experience but not sure if it could also be described as enjoyable.  There is a mass of humanity fighting for their own spot as they try to buy bargains off stall holders.  Tryto avoid the middle of the day.

We had heard so much about the floating market that we tried to go on 2 different days only to fins it not there. Very disappointing..... The street market is worth a look and has many different stalls and is very colourful

An amazing place, everything you could possibly need to buy is available in this market, a brilliant few hours spent exploring on foot. The range of fruits and vegetables available was awesome. We saw piles of Wood apples which  smell like blue cheese, but taste like sour tamarind pulp. if you are brave enough sample them - Made into a wood apple fruit shake, they can be excellent.

We got up early and took a tuktuk to the Pettah Market, as we are always intrigued by these local shopping experiences. Pettah is spread out over several blocks and is very busy with anything you could possibly ever want for sale. There is an open air vegetable and fruit section, which was cool, but we struggled to find food vendors and ended up eating in one of the small deceptively named “hotel” restaurants, which was fine, but nothing special. A fine morning spent, nosing around, but wouldn’t have missed it.

We came through Pettah as part of a walking tour.  We were there on a Sunday, so not all the stalls were open but it was still reasonably busy.  Each street within the 'market' sells different items such as fabrics, clothing, cleaning products, plastic flowers and fresh produce.  The fresh produce market was amazing, offering pineapples, bananas, pumpkins etc, dried fish and fresh herbs such as curry leaves.
Be ready to enjoy Asian street style market,shopping and stores and fully crowded people on roads.and speak loud so you can not hear your friend. Nice a couple of times on there
We came here to look at the mosque and loved the street vibes. I purchased the pickled fruits and palm jaggery. Lots of cafes here and stores selling everything that you may want.

This was a walk-through experience of the bazaar; crowded, noisy, hawkers extolling the virtue of their wares, it's colourful, you can buy just about anything here, although unsure of the quality.  The varieties of fruit and vegetables were mesmerizing, the dried fish had a very pungent smell, clothing, electronics, DVD's that work in your country Sir. I've forgotten most of the information imparted by our guide, too much overload. If you visit Colombo, Pettah Bazaar is a must, even if only to rub shoulders with the locals and just look at the array of produce on sale.

it was crowded, and for us not useful.we think pettah is as big as Delhi bazaar, but it wasn't. i bought some spicy. we cant find souvenirs like wooden elephants,mugs or any Sri Lanka stickers. there were lots of Sari shops there and you can find beautiful ones. as you are looking fr Sari or spicy, you can visit one of the most beautiful mosques in Sri Lanka there. we didn't buy any special things but it was nice to see people are coming and going. and if you want to find something for breakfast, it will be a little hard.

Pettah is the central trade hub of Sri Lanka. Extremely busy and crowded. Sort of unorganised, yet it is a great arena to get a good understanding of Sri Lankan context and experience all walks of life. Further it is full of different varieties of food, street food, pickles, fruits etc. If you wanna take a closer look at the Sri Lankan trade, urban culture and way of life, it is a place you should be. Advice is to take an early morning or an evening tour to avoid scorching sun.
Arguably most famous street shopping place in the island country. Be careful here before yiu commit to buy and bargain very hard
This is one of the most famous street shopping place in country. You will get everything here and ensure you bargain really well here.

An excellent place to spend a couple of hours when in Colombo. Right opposite the Bus and Train station so easy to find. Leather is the thing to buy and barter for. A real leather, yes real, belt for 200rps.

You haven't done an Asian country unless you've battled its local market. Adjacent to the railway station makes it easy to get here. Absolutely packed and full of locals, which is always a good sign. Muslim male traders dominate here. Check the quality carefully especially of the clothing. Very hot and thirsty work, but if you like a market challenge go for it.

Pettah is an iconic symbol of Colombo. Pettah impressed me with her madness and chaos. The market area itself is so rowdy and congested. Lorries, trucks and wagons conveying loads of cargoes, pushed their way mercilessly and ruthlessly through the narrow alleys. If you are not alert and cautious, the reckless driver may just knock you down. The agricultural produce from the rural areas and the overseas import all arrived here either for the market sale or for storage in the warehouses. Cheap toys, fruits, electrical products, garment and a myriad of local produce are displayed in shops and on floors sometime obstructing pedestrian walkway. I was surprised to see exotic fruit like durians among the many market display. I had pure coconut drinks from a hawker  who sold me one coconut for 60 rupees. The intense heat of the afternoon sun made me thirsty and drinking healthy fresh coconut juices helped to quench my thirst instantly. Do try the local orange coconut if you are at the market. I visited the Old Town Hall and the staff reluctantly opened a wax museum room at the second floor showcasing the colonial government municipal officials hold their meeting at the Old Town Hall during the British days. I also visited the stunningly impressive `Red Mosque' and a Hindu temple in the vicinity of this market. A Clock Tower stands proudly at a road junction of Pettah. It is a maze wandering around Pettah and every bustling street has something to boast about on the merchandise sold. At one street, it was all the clothing and garment. At another street, it was all the electronic products and hardware. The public bus 187 from the airport ended at Pettah and the terminal is located on a slip road across the Colombo Fort Train Station. I came to Pettah on my last day in Sri Lanka not only to explore Pettah but also to board this public bus to the airport.  I only paid 60 rupees for the whole journey from Pettah to the airport. But a word of caution, do not take this bus if you are rushing to the airport. The journey took more than an hour as it stopped at every bus stops to fetch passengers. You are deemed not to have visited Colombo if you did not visit Pettah.
Local markets, with plenty of bargains with fruits, freens and other items.  Even if you just want to stroll around to look at some of the local merchandise.

Spent a couple of hours exploring road after road around the area which is Pettah. If you want to find a gift to take home to your family and friends you’ll find it here for a reasonable price. It’s a bit hectic in places but you don’t really get hassled which is a bonus. Also came across an amazing Mosque and Hindu temple which you can go into. Full of locals which is always good sign.

A bustling, crowded, manic Market right in the City with a great array of merchandise and food. Like vendors are crowded together - e.g. a row of mobile phone shops then a row of clothes shops.  Curious, but obviously effective.
Decent place for shopping. Not very big. Can be covered by walk within 1 hour. good area to walk around in the evening. Not many stuffs to buy.
This place is rush and full of food, clothes, things you (not) need. A spot to must to see, maybe crazy, maybe noise, but at lest try coconut or buy mango.

My friend and I (both 24, from the UK) visited Pettah Market on our first day in Sri Lanka, and got a bit of a shock. Although the market itself was lovely to see, we felt very uncomfortable as some of the local men paid us very unwanted attention. Both of us were felt up as we were walking in crowds, and a couple of men followed us for ten minutes. When we decided to get in tuk tuk to get away, one man tried to get in with us and we had to push him out. We hadn’t read anything about this kind of behaviour before visiting so wanted to let people know this can happen, especially to young women on their own. A bad start to the trip but it has got much better since leaving the city.

I love markets and Pettah wasn't a disappointment! Everything from sumptuous silks and ridiculously cheap bags and shoes, to an amazing selection of dried fish, all the spices and wonderful exotic fruit and vege. I could have spent days wandering this crazy busy market but only had a few hours. Sadly the ONE thing I really wanted to buy - vanilla beans - I couldn't get bc it was the wrong season. I made do with a bunch of silk sarees (only buy if you know what you are doing. There are some VERY good imitation silks and they aren't so hot on giving you a snippet to do a burn test)  and some clothes for the kids and husband.

We visited in the hope of buying some souvenirs and visiting a local traditional market. This place is absolutely crazy and crowded with people (mostly locals and only few tourists). We expected to find both good and bad quality items but unfortunately most of them were bad quality. People over there are open to negotiating and some items can be purchased even 40-50% cheaper than the initial offer so bargain if you want something.

Pettah Market is the best place to find a huge variety of beautiful souvenirs which you can buy for the cheapest prices. If you want the best deals, you may even bargain with the merchants! It’s an exciting experience that every tourist in Colombo should have!

Visited with my daughter looking for souvenirs Mainly phones and produce Poor quality bags not many souvenirs to buy .Disappointing.People friendly and did not cause any hassle but I couldn't recommend it

Loved it. Gorgeous cheap products and nice sellers that allow you to haggle. Different foods available, including snacks and fruits. It’s such a pleasant place that no one would resist the temptation of buying something from this market.

If you wish to experience crowds in Srilanka, can visit Pettah. Most of the items sold is cheap and not of good quality, better to go with the local people, like your guide, driver who helps you bargain and ask any other queries you have.

Most of the people will only arrive Colombo on the last day of your trip. Pettah market has a really good bargain for fridge magnets, keychains, leather items, decorations plates, mugs, etc. The cost of fridge magnet as low as 50rupees and at the average of 100-150 rupees. You can buy a mug at 400 rupees each. (Bought 3) Bargain skills is needed here. But don't overdo it untill u press the seller. If u think the price is reasonable for you, stop bargaining. If you are looking for a good materials of t shirts, I would suggest go to ODEL Luv SL instead. They have much better quality and good designs with affordable price (starting from 1150 rupees - 1950 rupees). For good options for Tea, LAKSALA would be the best place. Hope this helps. Hope this help.

A visit to Sri Lanka would not be complete without a local visit to Pettah. Similar to other reviews, it's busy, crowded and chock full of fun.  We enjoyed walking through crowds and checking out everything from electronic goods to vegetables.  It felt like we were walking through a National Geographic magazine and would recommend adding this to one's itinerary.

Pettah is a crowded place, consisting of by lanes, located near Colombo Fort Railway Station, which is most popular for local street market. The visitors can buy all sorts for items at cheap rate and also bargain for more. The most people here appeared to be in hurry to reach their destination. There are many eateries in the area serving food at reasonable price. The place is not unique and can avoided. However, visit Pettah to shop at bargain price and to experience the busy pace of life in the city.

It seems like the whole world must have descended on this place  - a manic tangle of people and traffic in amongst the shops and street traders. There is of course also the magnificent mosque and temple - not to be missed.

If you love street shopping, pettah market is the place to be in Sri lanka. Each lane has lots of shops. From chocolates, bags, electrical items you can find almost everything here. The clothes sold on the street may not be of great quality buy then the price is low too. Head here to shop. If not enjoy the buzz.

I don't recommend it to most people but if you want to get a real experience with almost no tourists this is an interesting market to visit. Lot of random market items but good food. Like to take time to roam again and try more snacks. If you’re eating at a nearby “restaurants” be prepared to eat with your hands or bring your own fork!
The most famous Street shopping place in Lanka. However you need to be very careful with prices here, if you bargain well, you can shop a lot
The most famous place for street shopping in Lanka. Also only place where you can bargain. Beware as you can taken for ride if don't know local language.

The best place to buy cheap souvenirs (key chains, clothes etc). All other places (Kandy, Mirrissa etc) we went to were quite expensive in comparison. Not many shops available but the choices of items are plenty.

This place is opposite to Colombo fort railway station. The area is always busy. Ppl come here to buy some cheap stuff. From clothes to electronics, u can find everything in this place. Have to bargain to get a good price.
We took a tuk tuk around the pettah and took some photos.  We had wanted to shop but it was all a bit grotty for us , particularly with a child.   The driver warned us about oick pockets too

You can find cheap electronic and clothings here. Be aware about electronic shopping . If you are a tourist dont do shopping here . You can just buy bags and srilanka tshirts at cheap cost. And fruit market is good . So colorful and u find loads of varieties . Drink tender coconut . Its yummy.

Omg! Loved it. Awesome cheap food and snacks. Easy to navigate. Best to bargain hard. I bought lots of cheap clothing, scarves, sunglasses, socks and fabric.  Go early to beat the crowds and foot/bike/car/cart traffic.  Get your spices and fruit here! Some places are wholesale only, but they will have a sign out the front. Keep you belongings close to you, but I never had a problem.

We really enjoyed our visit to Pettah Market. It's massive and sprawling so I recommend planning your route first (we didn't do this and I think we missed some of the good stuff because of it). It's definitely worth visiting the fruit and vegetable section. The stall holders were friendly and very kind, they were happy for us to take photos and sample/ask questions about some of the fruits we had never seen before. Trust me, don't try the sour cherries, they are like "toxic waste" (disgusting kids sweets) but a million times worse. I caused much hilarity when I innocently tasted!

Pettah Market is a huge area NE of the station and you can almost buy anything you want here, from clothes, fruit, car parts, spices. You name it, they have it! I found the fruit market quite interesting and makes for good photography, but i visited on a Sunday when most stores and stalls in Pettah are closed.

Walked from our hotel to the market which took about 20 minutes. Found it easily the second time around! The first time we came via the railway station, we arrived at 'shoe' row and at the end turned left instead of right, so thought that was it! The second or next day we came we turned right and ended up in electric street and then haberdashery row. The roads are very busy with stalls from the shops flowing on to the road, so no paths to walk on and plus one has to contend with the numerous tuck tuck transporting through. One also has to watch out for the barrows which are full of goods or dropping off stuff at shops. Bedsides the shops there are also lots of little alleyways which have shops in and sell things at reasonable prices. We didn't see all the market as it was too manic and I was frightened that my feet were going to be run over! In this area is THE DUTCH MUSEUM which we were hoping to visit but when we went it was closed for renovations (roof looked off) so not sure when it is due to reopen as sign didn't state!

The market stretches for about 1KM and small shops lined both sides of the road and is located next to fort. Foreigners need to be careful as vendors increases the price once they see you are foreign. Lookout for price tags. Otherwise a great place to visit where you can find souvenirs, clothes, bags and crafts.

This is an amazing market to walk through - or rather push you way through. It is very busy and there is just so much to see. If you want it . - you can get it her. I particularly liked the fruit and vegetable area - just so much different types of fresh food available. If crows are a problem - go on a Sunday  - yes a lot of the shops are closed but the crowds are much less!

great to walk through the market . Yes it is crowded but lovely fresh veg and fruit. We had our first King Coconut drink on the street there. If you have been to SE Asian markets before you will notice that this market is run by men rather than women. It is very busy as people are working to make a living. Enjoy it for what it is, a great experience in Siri Lanka.
This is the kind of place that you loved 10 years ago. Now you can find all these items on internet. Mainly local people. Mostly salesmen. Not so many customers. Not worth the trip.
If you can spare the time, walk the streets, take it all in. You can walk amongst the locals and see the vibrant colors the loud noises and inviting smells of the street food. Worth the visit.

I was expecting a huge,bustling vibrant market but what we saw was a disappointment.Lots of gear if you are a man with shoes,clothes etc but very little if you are after the exotic or unusual.Maybe we were there at the wrong time but there was little of interest for me and that is unusual.Go and have a look but it wouldn't be somewhere I would return to

The Pettah Market is an amazing place if you don't mind crowds and hectic streets full of vendors and shoppers and vehicles. It is the main 'local' market of Colombo with streets crushed full of people, goods and vehicles. It feels completely chaotic yet when explored on foot you will find streets dedicated to certain merchandise. In one street you will find bags, backpacks and suitcases, in another clothing and fabrics and so on. Prices are cheap but you will need to haggle to get the best deals. This is basically a local market so not the greatest place to find souvenirs and gifts of quality but it is an exciting shopping experience for personal and household basics.

This place will give you a great feel for Sri lanka with its narrow streets crowded with vendors and tuktuks. It is not a tourist trap, but mainly for locals to buy home goods, clothing and food. There are even vendors selling second hand goods. Prices are not fixed so you will need to haggle to get a good bargain. Clothing quality is not high, but neither are prices and it is colourful and worth buying even if it does fall apart after a few uses. Vendors can be seen pulling carts, pushing barrows and with bicycles loaded with goods. It is an excellent place to simply stand (no seating!) and watch people. You will get a really authentic look at how Sri Lankans live. On one end is the railway station, on the other (close to the Fort area) there is a food court hidden away a bit which serves locals some exceptionally good curries.

Spent a couple of hours here by myself.  The streets and shops here have by far the worst traffic I have ever seen anywhere, however, this is surprisingly charming.  Though I got absolutely baked in the sun, this was an exhilarating and enjoyable experience.  Not for the faint hearted!

This is a bustling collection of market streets. It’s for locals, so mostly modern home goods, not much stuff a tourist would be after, although there are plenty of prayer necklaces, fabrics and spices. The roads are narrow and footpaths are rare, so it’s slow and dangerous going amid the traffic. There are churches, mosques and the old town hall towards the eastern side. Restaurants seem uncommon in the middle streets but there are clusters near the station and the old town hall, plus juice and fruit stalls.

Easy to walk around through the narrow streets but be aware of the tuk tuks and vehicles moving through the area. The pathways are so narrow you end up walking on he road so do be careful. Interesting to see the local produce and products. Areas are arranged with products grouped together - ie all electronics in one area, phones in another, bags and leatherwear together etc. After walking through the local area you can cross the main road and head towards the railway station and there is a small more tourist type of market. Interesting they sell the same clothing at double or triple the cost of the same items in the local market across the main road!

Pettah is a typical developing country inner-city, major marketplace. It is crowded, noisy, colorful and a great place for local products and produce.  Blocks and blocks of stalls with a wide variety of things to buy.  Be ready to negotiate for everything.  Relax and enjoy the circus.

One has to be brave, I mean very brave to behave like a local. Plenty to sight, plenty of music or was that noice of honking and yes...smell smell smelly. But at the same time so much to see feel and experience. Do be careful with your belongings just lime any other such public places rlund the world. My personal bad experience was in Milan... don't want to talk about it....

We spent around 2 hours walking around the markets around pettah. The area is extremely busy and it can take a long time to get into the area and out with hectic traffic everywhere. The streets are also very busy. If coming to this area head to the spice markets which smell and look incredible. We bought several spices which were very fresh and for a small fee.

If you are in to street photography, this is the most amazing and best place in Sri Lanka. The busy crowd, busy sellers, porters, the little shops at the side of the streets and everything is there for street photography.  It is an amazing experience walking in narrow streets with your camera and knowing about the people of Sri Lanka and having photography. The best time is for photography is 8AM – 10Am. Most of people would love to face your photographs. But first get the permission from them politely before you do photography of them. Definitely they would love and give you the permission. Highly recommended for the street photographers!!!!

The Pettah Market is situated in the suburb of Pettah in the city of Colombo. The entrance to the Pettah Market is marked by a tall monument known as the Khan Clock Tower. It’s an open air fresh market, which sells electronics, clothes, shoes, jewelry, fast-food, vegetables and fruits etc. It’s a massive crowded place with jam-packed of people. One can literally find everything from clothes to travel equipment to food to electrical items to toys. It's a crazy, loud, chaotic, crowded and infinitely full of interesting and useful things. It’s is horrible to visit the place during hot and humid day.

If you are in Colombo and up for some cheap shopping, this is your place. There are hundreds of stalls selling almost each and everything you can imagine about. Pretty handy and the prices are cheap as well. This being very close to the Fort railways station and the central bus station makes it very crowded most of the time. There are some good local food options in this area.

This is the Hub for shopping in Sri Lanka!  Products can be categorized Street wise and area wise. Cheaper than rest of the island. Extremely crowded. avoid Fridays and Sundays. Take extra precaution against pick pockets racketeers and fraudsters . Always shop from established shops.Be careful about street vendors. Bargains are common .

One of the top sites we wanted to visit while in Colombo was the Pettah market. Not the floating one but the older, more authentic market along Keyzer Street. Its a huge area, broken into various parts according to various produce and goods. So remember to put on a good pair of walking shoes. It will take awhile. Its also a photographer's dream. Loads of colours, smells and sounds and if you are sporting enough, taste too. We arrived in the morning in a metered tuk tuk and started with the vegetables and fruits segment. Please refer to attached photos. Vendors are friendly but please be polite and ask for their permission before taking their picture or produce. We also had tea at a cute tea stall and chatted with the locals while taking turns with our cameras. There is also an old railway musuem set within the market, next to a very clean public toilet. Pettah is also closely located to several touristy sites. So ask around and if you do take a tuk tuk, which we advise, get a metered one so you dont get ripped off. People are pretty honest but better to be safe.

If you want to do road side shopping this is the best place to do it. You can start with the batik shops and the bag shops. You can buy dresses to wear at home by road side - for the same stuff you need to pay at least 3 or 4 times the price in a shop or mall. We purchased a footwear for 350 rupees. The same one was priced 1000 rupees in a mall. the quality was the same. Be choosy in your purchase. Do not miss out on having a cup of tea or some bites in one of bakery. If you have time on hand and just want to walk around to shop then this is the place. There are also streets which you can avoid.

Horrible. Dirty. Air full of exhaust fumes and the stench of dried fish. Unless you're looking for groceries, there's literally nothing worth seeing or buying at the market. No interesting souvenirs or fashionable items of clothing. Lots of junk. Not a patch on a Bangkok or HCMC market.

This is a very crowded place. Lots of activities featuring the locals, lots of trading and sales happening around the Pettah market. You can get some decent souvenirs here for very decent prices too. Some of the historical buildings are very well preserved too. Visit this market to have a feel of the local Sri Lankan life.
Pettah is a must see part of Colombo. It's always busy/bustling day and night. Lost of shops/sights/places to eat. Make sure you visit.

This looked like the main market area of Colombo. I saw this first on my bus ride from airport to the city center and was impressed with the cleanliness of the vegetable market section. Later in the evening taking the city tour we went by these streets several times. Some great old buildings there but the market as such was very average.

Nice market but not impressive. Lots of stuff at good reasonable prices. Many alleys for souvenirs. Many local vendors selling fruits, vegetables, handmade bags, textiles, fish and almost anything you need.

This market has most of the daily stuff that you need. Not an amazing market but should be able to find the stuff you wish to find in reasonable local prices. Not very fancy in varieties and all the stalls are quite spread out. Many locals wondering around and many goods-carrying men along the road.

If you plan on going to Pettah Markets with any sort of shopping plan, forget about it. Just make sure you've got your most comfortable walking shoes on and embrace the chaos. For the other reviews that comment on no souvenirs, there are whole alleyways dedicated to just that. If you want to escape the chaos and experience the markets, the best time is around 10am when the streets are a little less hectic. Enjoy fellow travellers.

A real taste of Sri Lanka, to be honest. This is where the people come to shop for fruits, vegetables, fish, textiles and everything they need, see the real market and get into the crowd, tuk tuks, local vendors...
Don't go! This is a mad house. Full of crammed streets and bedlam. The Dutch museum was supposed to be our escape but it was rubbish.

A very congested, noisy and fragmented market. Great if you are after LED GU10 light bulbs, cabling for your tuk tuk or a sack of onions, but frustrating and tiring if you're looking for a Sri Lankan souvenir or local delicacies. Stall vendors seemed dismissive of tourists, further creating a distant atmosphere. Not what you typically feel when in an Asian market. In summary, good to spend 10 mins here to get a flavour, then briskly proceed to your next destination.

To begin with its absolutely not a place for people who are finicky, who are looking for sophistication. It’s totally a place who has open mind to see what all the city has to offer. This is something very fascinating. There are lots of shops selling bags, chapels, clothes, handmade bags, souvenirs, (all not great quality) electronic, fruits and veggies and many more things. We walked around in the market to get the feel of the place. For me I really enjoyed window shopping here and at last gulped 2 fresh coconut water from and old man selling fresh coconuts.
Busy area, lots of local stuff to see and buy. Need to be careful with all the people traffic and vehicle traffic. This is where the locals shop.

Many choices and options! I think that Pettah market is cheapest place in Colombo. Even Negombo people, when they need to do big shopping, they just visit here since Pettah's price is much cheaper than Negombo.
Fun to visit. This is where the locals shop, and it's more of a fun trip than good shopping. Don't miss the street with only plastic flowers!

The market is set over several streats which are packed with people, men transporting goods on huge trolleys and cars and tuk tuk drivers trying to drive through the chaos. We didn't buy anything here, i was looking for clothes and souvenirs but found most of it was cheaply made tat. We also visited a market nearer to Fort railway stat ion but again very cheaply made clothes and these athings ridiculous prices too.

Pettah market in Colombo is the place that sells everything and anything you can possibly imagine.  I first visited this market more than a decade ago to buy supplies to take east on a post tsunami humanitarian mission.  Since then I've bought gold jewelry, yoga mats, kitchen gear, new shoes, you name it, you can get it in Pettah.  If you want to throw yourself into the heart of Lankan life and mix with the locals then head to Pettah.  It will be a hot and sweaty adventure but don't worry too much, when you're feet get tired and you've had enough, some lovely shop keeper will pull out a seat and a cold Sprite for you and let you rest for a moment.  Often missed but well worth a look is the beautiful mosque built in 1909 and which used to be Colombo's main landmark for sailors coming into port.  TOP TIP:  It's better to be respectful of local customs and dress more conservatively - women with shoulders and knees covered.

A friend and I visited here to get a sense of Colombo. The heat and the traffic chaos frustrated us greatly. You need to keep alert for tuk tuks, cars, motorcyclists, and other pedestrians - no mindless meandering here. Still, it's worth it to get a flavour of old Colombo. Wander down different streets and experience the different trades and wares for sale on each - e.g., textiles, foodstuffs.

There are several markets in the Pettah area.  We saw the bazaar (flea markets) and then walked up to the Federation of Self-Employed Market (which seems to be known as the FOSE market) which is near the chaotic bus station.  The FOSE market has both flea market and fruit and veg at the rear.  We then walked through the back streets towards the Fort area (only about 3kms in total).  The back streets are where the wholesale action is - fruit and veg, textiles, electronics, clothing and footwear and who knows what else.  A hive of activity.  Well worth an hour or two of wandering around.

We found the actual Pettah Market with all its produce to be of interest; just to see the variety of fresh vegetables and fruit that Sri Lankans consume. As far as the ambience was concerned, we found it to be rather dull and roughish. However, the streets surrounding the market are far more interesting in that they are filled with colourful array of street stalls selling various goods. There were shops selling such items as sandals designed and manufactured in Sri Lanka, saris and colourful materials, tea, herbs and spices, electronic goods, mobile phones, short-eats, and other street vendor food. We did not see any public toilets within this area. As for parking, our Guide found a convenient paid parking lot that allowed us to wander through the shopping streets mentioned above, before visiting the Pettah Market.

Not a market as such except for the small fruit & vegetable market in the eastern area of the district. Fascinating area to walk around in the narrow streets and see the hive of activity going on. A lot of wholesale and trading going on. Not targeted to foreign tourists at all.

Extremely crowded.. More suitable for locals.. Went searching for spices on a hot 31st December morning.. Best time to go early in the day by @11am..bought cardamom (claimed first grade) 1kg for SR2000 and Black Pepper 1kg for SR1500. Nothing else was of interest to us.
The pettah floating market doesn't have much accept for a few food places and about 8 small shops that sell local curios! I enjoyed the walk but not much shopping choices...

This was our first stop in Colombo, but amazingly Trip Advisor doesn't seem to feature it.It is a very interesting museum, the only one in the world devoted to the era of Dutch colonisation. The Dutch were in Sri Lanka for more than a century before the British took over.
If you've been to Mumbai or another crowded SE Asian city, this market is pretty much the same. Bargains galore for cheaply made goods.

In Pettah you'll find the product of all price ranges. You'll get everything like: food, clothing, toy, cosmetics, gift item almost everything. It's better to go with tuktuk there. Here you can bargain as much as you want. If you are accompanying with local people, tell them to fix the price. Otherwise they'll not less the price whenever they can understand that you are a foreigner. And this place is very crowded.

We took a TukTuk to The Pettah Market and he dropped us off in front of the Fort Colombo Train Station. While we never encountered the Floating Market, we did find the local Market in Pettah a few blocks away, after asking a young woman for directions. This is where locals shop for food, clothing, fabric, luggage, bags, hardware and etc. It is crowded and full of life. An interesting way to spend a couple of hours as we walked up and down the streets. They do not necessarily sell Tourist items, but, we were happy to purchase electrical converters for under $1, and a cheap suitcase (an alibaba import). We saw many tea and snack shops.
To crowded and very dirty. A lot of things they sell, but I dont like anything. When they see tourist from Europe, price are much bigger. If you have small children,dont go there.

Right by the main road from Colombo Fort station is the Pettah floating market and the Pettah market, where it is said shopping can be done cheap. The place is crowded during the day and we can find many clothing, luggage/baggage, fancy accessories' stores all along the market. There are few restaurants as well.
Very dirty, crowded and expensive. Everyone wants to get money from tourists. I would rather avoid it
Colombo is a busy city but the atmosphere at Pettah is unique. You should just take your time and make a little stroll down the different streets of Pettah

When we went we were the only westerners/clear tourists around. Shops filled with all kinds. People avidly selling everything from pants to plugs. We had a good wander around. Amazing haberdashers and material shops. Nothing here is super high quality, but interesting for a walk around. Tips: even though they're shops you can still haggle Many shops closed during midday prayers as this is a majority Muslim area.

Pettah is a long road with shops selling all kinds of stuff. From clothes to car parts. They have knots everything there and it's known to be cheaper than other places. It's all open air and quite crowded during the day. You have to walk In Between the lanes as cars can get stuck inside or use a tuk tuk. We saw the Jami ul Alfar mosque here. It was a good experience and it's not a bad place to visit but coming from Pakistan we have similar stuff in Lahore so it wasn't something different and I probably won't go to it again as its not where I would like to shop but if you're a tourist in Colombo do visit it; also try and visit the floating market which we couldn't due to the time constraints.

This is superb place to shop if someone is fond of economical shopping. I could not bargain much, but felt no need to do it beyond some point as things are really very cheap. Gets crowded in the evening, but if you are travelling light and can manage well in crowd, it's nice place to shop for clothes, fabrics, shoes, toys and purses etc.
Very Good place  for shopping with bargaining.  You will get  a -z  things  at this market with good ambiant surroundings.

This is the place to go if you haven't been to SE Asia and witnessed the throngs of people and the hustle and bustle and sounds and smells that go with it.  Hard to drag kids around in the heat but it's worth an hour or two to show the kids how the locals live and be thankful for what they have before heading to an air conditioned mall for a drink.

Full of men only on stalls, making comments on the women passing by. Aggressive annoying stall holders who try to block your way and grab you by the arm to buy from them.. Stay away, especially if a woman.

We explored the side streets and main streets, then the fruit and veg market. It is worth seeing just to experience if you have never been to the real Sri Lanka. Once you've seen it, I think you are done and can move on. It felt safe and non threatening, just very busy and noisy, a lot for everyone to take in. Being English, haggling is not in the dna so these places are always hard going. We did stumble across a very basis tea shop that serve us well with hot sweet tea and cold drinks. We were pleased in the end to jump in the tuk tuk and go to somewhere less crazy and with a bit more shade and air con. There's only so much you can take.

Don't miss the opportunity to walk around and mix with locals. The market is very buzy and crowded, but that's the way a market should be. There is a lot to see, to buy and to eat. If your're not comfortable walking in these crouwds, we can assure you that it is a safe place. We also walked by a Dutch museum (500rs each), but didn't enter.
Nice lively area with markets, fresh fruit and loads of good food. Worth a visit, make sure you have a little appetite and ask the fruit merchants to cut the fresh fruit you've just bought!

In our short stay in Colombo, Pettah definitely stood out as a place to visit. Even if you do not need to buy anything, it is a fantastic place to wander around and see what is on offer, the millions of different good being sold and transported, and the charismatic vendors selling them. While there, have a bite of some fresh pineapple with chilli powder, a lovely treat to accompany your gander ;)
The Pettah is the original bazaar or street market in Colombo. The web of narrow streets have numerous specialist shops. For example, jewellery and gold shops are largely on Sea street.
Pettah Market available for Wholesale and retails as well very cheap compare to other places, terrible traffic very crowded. safety first....

No offence it is very crowded, when i was walking on the street automatically my mind alerted me better be safe from pick pocket, but nothing such that happen , people are good here. The market is very big wholesale market , prices are less from other places.

Come here only if you are a diehard shopaholic, else you will feel exhausted and over whelmed. Also having a reliable Sinhalese friend is recommended as the real good shops are hidden in the labyrinth and finding them is a task in itself.
We went to see the market. It's very busy place and people are shutting. Uncomfortable and boring. I am not recommend in this place.

Pettah is very close to Colombo Fort rail/bus station. On the main road there are several shops that sell most items one would like to purchase including some Chinese items.  There are several restaurants available on the main road.  I didn't enter the cut streets where more shops are there.  Pettah is a busy and large area of Colombo city.  From here out-station buses ply.

This is the oldest area in Colombo. It won't be everyone's cup of tea, but the experience will be much closer to the real Clombo than wandering around old colonial buildings. It is a colourful, vibrant and teeming commercial area, where most items, many fake, can be viewed and bought, from second hand shoes and recycled oil drums to expensive jewelry. There are many churches and temples of all faiths including the remarkable Jami-Ul-Alfar Mosque with candy striped red and white brick work. The best of the markets is the Federation of Self Employees off Olcott Mawatha and near Fort railway station. However the real charm is the friendliness and willingness of the people to let you closely examine and photo every and any unusual activities (to Western eyes) that you can bump into around many corners. It is a safe and friendly if slightly chaotic neighbourhood.

A must see if visiting adjacent Colombo Fort area or arriving at Fort Railway station. The Pettah is crowded, hot and bustling but not at all threatening. You can just wander around the streets watching and exploring the hive of activity that surrounds you. You can be constantly surprised by what you discover just around a corner, be it a flower market, a beautiful brown and white tiled mosque or a banana grower's laneway. The market is an assault on your senses. Just remember to have water and a sun hat with you!

We spent few hours wondering the streets of this busy market with each street selling different wares. The fruit and vegetable market was very enjoyable. We broke our walk with a number is stops for cold drinks/fruit juices and strong tea. It was quite enjoyable.

Fun area to visit if you're visiting Colombo. We visited on a Sunday so lots of things were closed, but it was still really lively and gave us a chance to see a bit more of a local side of Colombo life. I really enjoyed it, so lovely and fun!

we just came here to buy a few trinkets and have a little wondering I've been here quite few times before but this time I was with my fiancé so I didn't drag him to too many shops this trip - otherwise they have shop after shop of craft/ costume  jewellery and really jewellery: fabrics and more .. omif you end up doing. more shopping than planned then you are in the right place to buy a cheap suitcase to get your purchases home dress a little more modestly in this area otherwise you will get stared at - and not in a complementing way if you decide to go for a huge wonder talk water with you as most of the shops here just don't sell bottled water for some reason we didn't have a meal when we visited this area and nothing really stood out for is so of you are slightly fussy make sure you visit on a full stomach I'll always love this place and visit every trip it's so colourful and is good to see everyday people getting on with their day some areas in pettah can be extremely difficult to cross the road and we were lucky when a local ushered us across 6 lanes of traffic Sri Lankans are such kind and thoughtful people :)
A great place to fully experience local shopping and wholesale markets, lots to see and smell!! Worth a visit and just be prepared for lots of people, traffic and activity.

We went to Pettah just to see want kind of things they sell.The shops are not reliable and the things are overpriced.Its crowded.They reduced price to very little after bargaining.This is not the worth the visit.Still we can go there to check out the Wolvendaal Church,Jami Ul-Alfar Mosque and Dutch Museum.

We took the train to Colombo Fort and wandered through the streets of the market. The fruit and veg were colourful and SO fresh looking. There were lots of stalls selling anything and everything. A bit too crowded for my liking but a real experience!

Being from India, we are accustomed to crowd and noise but this is mayhem. This resembled Chennai's bus terminal area (Parry's corner) about 20 years back. Not worthy place to visit but for interchanging from airport (airport coach no. 183 drops you off here). Both long distance private and government buses (to Kandy, Anuradhapura etc) leave from here as well as the Fort (Colombo's main) railway station is closeby.

I got the information through  some of the reviews. I thought I could buy some clothes here. There is little bit difference between the market which is there adjacent to the fort. Pettah is a place full of shops relates to clothes, electronic accessories.In pettah most of the shops are whole sale dealers. There is one market besides fort railway station. I strongly advice you not to go this market unless you are master in bargaining. very rude people. They quote double the price. I still suggest those who want to buy clothes visit 'house of fashions' or 'nolimits' in galle road

Pettah is a very noise and crowded local market. It is great for photo opportunity but  you have to be careful from street vendors, rickshaw, and cars passing by you when taking photo. Not suggest to travel with young children as the streets are abit dangerous and crowded during the day time.
one can find good bargain in clothes and other Accessories while searching for thing of interest, It is very much near to Colombo fort Railway Station

The market is busy, hot, noisy, chaotic but altogether vibrant and authentic. Judging by the number of locals shopping here, it is not just another tourist trap but a popular local shopping area. Might be a bit too much for some, especially in the searing heat, but still an authentic experience.

On a hot or rainy day, you have to brace yourself for the crowds. The people are smiles but everyone is rushing to go somewhere. I would go with a walking tour and if you're looking for something specific. Otherwise it's really manic and crowded on the busy weekends.

Crowed market selling boxer shorts, socks, sunglasses, shoes and SIM cards. We picked up some cheap sandals for our trip but there no gifts to buy for our friends. This is definitely more suited for locals or tourists who need to buy something practical. A disappointing experience.

This is the place to go if you want to buy fabrics, Indian kurtas, sarongs etc.  It's hot, crowded and noisy, but if it is a market your looking for this is a good one!  You can bargain here for goods.  Some old buildings scattered around too.

We were slightly disappointed with the market. It was very apparent that we were the only non-locals in the market, and as such it was quite intimidating. We made our way quickly through the markets to the Dutch Period Museum - didn't linger.

It's the actual life style and goods market where you should go. The streets are narrow and busy all the times,  you can find anything easily out there.. Fruits, clothing,  souvenirs are easily available.

The Pettah Market is the soul of Colombo. Most of the tourist destinations around the world have a glitzy side as well as a real side. The glitz loving tourist crowd lives in posh hotels, travels in new chauffeur driven cars, eats in famous restaurants, buys expensive machine made souvenirs sold as handicrafts and departs thoroughly satisfied that they have seen another city. But many tourists try to see the real city, the people, the smells, the streets, the local foods..... the ACTUAL city. Pettah is the actual city....a wonderful combo of elegant shops on a main road and hundreds of small shops and kiosks in a maze of adjoining streets. Me and my wife went there on 10 November 2015 and spent hours in this chaotic market and loved it. Cutlery, shoes, cloth, fruits, gift items, handicrafts, imitation jewelry, shirts, sarongs.... everything was displayed there in hundreds of shops and stalls. The streets were filled with people and tuk-tuks and hand driven carts and mobile vendors, everyone expertly finding out a way to move forward without hitting each other. The prices in Pettah Market are very real, compared to the tourist shops where guides take you. You can expect a bargain of 10-15% at the most. There are big showrooms on the main road where the prices are a bit higher but they also offer huge varieties. Don't miss Pettah, because only here you come face to face with the real Colombo....!

This market is the source of fresh fruits, vegetables, fish and spices for restaurants and private citizens of Columbo.  We had the lucky timing of visiting during peak season for fruit.  Many varieties, some only seen here for the first time, were available.  The sellers are very eager to either sell you fruit or have their pictures taken.  This is an important site to see.  Go early in the day, so the stalls are plentiful and before the heat brings on a stomach-churning putrid odour.  Word is, this market will be re-located to a more appropriate facility/ location within the year. 😉

Pettah, with its main Bus Stand and Colombo Fort Railway Station and the markets (Manning Market, Pettah Market) is a chaotic maze of sorts. However, you'll be enchanted by how the locals go about their daily lives.

Arrived and departed by Tuk-Tuk.  THAT's an experience by itself.  Bargaining is expected.  Few establishments take foreign currency of any sort; credit cards are also not accepted.  There are some ATMs about but they lack universal connectivity.

Pettah market is best experience up close and personal. Enjoy walking to through the market to see farm fresh produce being sold. Experience orderly chaos through the many streets selling everything under the sun and then more.

Central busnd train stations are located in pettah including numourous numbers of shops and markets . This is not much of a nice place to go through since traffic is horrible and very crowded. Try to avoid / not to go through pettah as much as posibble.

We visited Pettah, which  is just east of Fort, on our first afternoon in Colombo.  It is busy, crowded and a great introdction into how retail business is done in Colombo.  There is a spice market, clothing market, fish market and produce market adjacent to one another.  The shopping streets are generally organized by product type - wedding invites and stationary, electronics, cloth and saris to mention a few.  You may not find anything to buy but it is fun to wander and look.

Pettah is the main whole sale and retail market of Colombo. You can fine large shops where small traders and bargain hunters visit for whole sale and retail buying. Some streets are dedicated for one kind of merchandize. It could be electrical goods, grocery items etc. Sarees are a specially in Pettah similar To T Nagar in Chennai. Streets are full of small time vendors selling all kinds of stuff. Bargain if you buy, pavement hawkers are nagging so be careful. If you want to experience the local behavior it is must visit even if you don’t want to buy anything. It is not recommended to take small children if you are travelling with family it is usually hot and kids will get bored.

We visited pettah market on a Sunday which meant that 1/3 of the shops were closed but that didn't really matter. Additionally, it was pouring with rain. We started off in the section next to the railway station. We basically were the only tourists around. We were quickly surrounded by stall owners that were handing us clothes like basic tops and comfi pants with different prints. After we tried a few things we decided to buy a top and one pair of pants. I was willing to spend 700-1000 rupiah in total. His proposed price was 4800 rupiah (30€). Having been all over Asia this price shocked me, especially after I bargained with tuk tuk drivers and I knew that they usually only go down about 1/10th or less of the proposed price. We immediately stopped bargaining and put down the clothes. He followed us all through the market, told other shop owners not to sell us anything, and insulted us all the time. He must have had a really bad day :). We bought two huge weekender leather bags for 9500 rupiah and decided to go out of this section. We crossed the street (pedestrian bridge) and just strolled the shops on the other side of the road. Everyone was so much friendlier and bargaining was fun again. At the end I bought those comfi print pants for 450 rupiah. I would suggest to start off at this side of the market and if you feel like it visit the other section but be prepared :P.

The life style in  the Pettah area has not changed for many years, it is a unique lifestyle. One has to go there to see it, it is very different from the rest of the Colombo city. The place is much cleaner than what it was. The stuff for sale on the pavements are mostly inferior quality, but worthwhile going to see the lifestyle of people who live there. The whole sale establishments have quality stuff. You have to be careful of Pickpockets & conmen,  they cheat even the locals, so foreign tourists should be more careful, better to go with a guide or some one who is reliable. There are some heritage buildings in the area, but not much for foreign tourists.

There is much better to see in Colombo. This area is filthy, the salesmen are aggressive and all of the wares that on sale are not worth the effort. We arrived here by tuk-tuk in the morning and left 2 hours later.

It is situated near colombo fort railway station (500 m only). There is so much hustle and bustle of life that as a family, we shortened our visit. This place was not as clean as rest of main district of colombo. Quality of clothing or shoes were not upto mark even prices were very cheap.

We just love Pettah, the bustle, the crowds, the shops and strange little things you'll find and buy, although you weren't looking for them, the temples and mosques .... Its a great place to get a saree or a salwar where the locals shop at a local price! Every one was friendly and treated us and our kids very kindly. And for us its one of the few areas in Colombo that are good for walking around! We spent several hours strolling and shopping, and came back the next day and the next! The only thing that was difficult to find was tasty food or even a restaurant with a manageable toilet (mainly for the kids aged 5 and 7). We'll definitely be back!

This is a huge public market where you can find almost anything from clothing to electronics.  Prices are cheap but the sellers don't negociate as much as in India. It's really worth it to spend half a day there.  I went there on a friday evening and a lot of shops were closing around 08:00 pm.
The real hustle and bustle of the market district of pettah. You might get lost but you can find yourself out quite easily. Very busy and active place. Quite enjoyable
This is the heart of Colombo.Where all the trading takes place.Lots of shops big and small selling all kinds of things you need.Good prices.

I really enjoyed Pettah. It was an experience to see the busy streets, the old shops... also it seems an authentic trading place rather than a tourist market (I didn't see any other tourists). People were very friendly and didn't mind if I took pictures of them. Because it's not a typical tourist market, it is not that great for shopping, unless you want to buy in bulk (a lot of shops are wholesale). Would definitely recommend going there but just for the experience rather than for shopping.

It's one of the most (probably the most)  famous shopping places in sri lanka. And I'm sure that is mostly due to the cheap rates and being able to get a great bargain. It has all the simple items, groceries, phones and accessories etc. It gets crowded almost everyday but that doesn't mean you run out of stuff to shop for. However, you better do some push ups and get ready for a hectic time at shopping among the huge crowd if you are planning to visit. You can get items at very cheaper prices compared to the market price if you are great at bargaining.

Pettah is a must for travellers wanting to experience the street market area of Colombo. It is a very busy part of the city, with narrow streets criss-crossing and 'zones' of merchandise including jewellery, electronics, clothing, backpacks and suitcases, food, stationary, home-ware and so on. One can get some interesting and good bargains here so it makes a good place for purchasing gifts, souvenirs and everyday requirements. It is very near to the bus stand and rail. It is a very busy area so be prepared to jostle with the many vendors and shoppers.

Pettah is an ideal place to buy stationary, plastic toys, veges, electronic items and equipment, clothes and other essential stuff in bulk. Ideal time to shop in the streets is before 11 am and after 4 pm. due to many crowds and business of the streets. Prince street is the busiest street, I feel. The Street is not carpeted and dust can be seen. Vendors are very helpful. It's good to just pop into Dutch Museum on your way wondering on the streets. 1st, 2nd Cross streets and Maliban streets are busy and connected with Prince street and Olcott Road. Olcott road and Prince Street lie in parallel to each other and connect with Central Bus Stand and Railway station on both ends respectively.
Area has narrow streets, busy shops, a great opportunity for people-watching amidst bustling street-life in the big city.
This a very good place for shopping for clothes and it is worth a visit to Dutch time museum at the same time.

Bustling with market stalls and shops that sells about everything. Shops were grouped into zones like textiles, jewelry, pots and pans, et all. Especially busy in the morning with the locals shopping and vendors moving goods around. Good spot to check out the sight, sound and smell of the locals' daily life.

One of the busiest places in Colombo where the main Colombo fort railway station and the bus stop are situated. This is the main point for taking or changing transportation from the airport. Gets very busy during the day and the traffic is terrible..

On all my trips, I always make time to visit a local market. You might not have anyting specific to buy but even if you do, it'll be for an extremely low price. Take the time to walk around and soak in the cultural experience. Sri Lankans are extremely friendly and welcoming. Don't be afraid to ask and talk to them. After walking a few, stop by one of the many food outlets to recharge.
This is the main market area of Colombo.Most of the whole sale trade takes place here.There are many shops and food  outlets also here.Close to the main Colombo railway station.

Pettah is a bustling market. In principle it sounds great but it was way too smelly and dirty for us. We took a ride through in a tuk tuk but that was enough and to be honest, I didn't spot anything I would really want to buy. Probably great if you really want to get into the more rustic side of Colombo but I think a lot of tourists would probably be better off staying clear.

Prepare to walk and get caught in a traffic jam! We always plan to visit all sorts if markets to get a feel of the place. Most are wholesale shops but we did buy small knicks and knacks for sourvenirs. Carry bottled water as its humid/hot. Struggle a little as we have a 5-year old with us and grandparents. The lovely red mosque is built in 1908 which is a nice surprise to stumble to and we like it. if you like to watch people and learn the life of people ... here's the place.

When visiting a new country, we always like to visit markets to get a feel for the place. So this was our first stop in Sri Lanka. You can't really really buy much there as most places are wholesale shops. But it is the people watching that is interesting. We walked most of it and some places have retail shop although there is nothing there that I would buy except for the 2 electrical adaptors which we needed (100 rupees each). In terms of market, we have seen many much better in the world but it is still interesting to help you see life in Sri Lanka.

Busy bustling market where you perhaps won't find anything good (or it will be crazily priced) but a good visit if you just want to experience Sri Lankan life. Yep, too many eyes and pestering calls if you are a young woman so be ready that this will truly be an experience of its own kind and definitely not a shopping trip.

After 30 minutes of aggressive touts pushing us to buy very poor quality merchandise in blistering heat we left! I have been to the weekend market in Bangkok and am not afraid of an unpleasant heat to buy decent items but this was very poor! Give it a miss and go to House of Fashion or another outlet and shop in comfort and peace.

An interesting place to see a Sri Lanka Market. It is very busy with many narrow side-streets. It gives a feel for the city and its origins. Despite the crowds it felt non-threatening If you intend to buy anything bartering is a must!.

The market is located opposite the Fort Railway Stn  and for anyone who like to explore markets this is the place to be. Most things can  be bought and are normally copies ,some good some plainly bad. bargaining is a must commencing at least 50% less than first quoted. There are side streets off side streets so care must be taken,saying this I did not feel threatened .Enjoy

If you are a shopping traveler, this is the only place you should go for shopping in Srilanka and nowhere else , because the rest if the island shops are none existed!!! It's weird but seem the whole island and other towns didn't have much offers or shop to buy souvenirs. So buy everything you need as souvenirs or gifts from here , because later you could not find anything ... Or even more expensive for the same thing .

The best local shopping in Sri Lanka can be done here. The bustling crowded streets will definitely remind you of the Indian shopping city lanes. You can get anything from traditional jewellery, famous ceylon tea, spices, local fashion to imported chinese goods, modern branded clothes and local food. You can get good bargains from street side vendors and avoid some of the expensive cloth shopping which you probably can get cheaper in India itself. You very easily get local auto rickshaws as 4 wheelers might find it difficult to navigate through the crowd.

I found it takes a little time to become accustomed to the hustle and bustle of this place, as well as the constant solicitation, some looks and some sneaky grabs (as a young woman), but you do walk out of here having a true and memorable cultural experience! I would recommend visiting the "federation of self employees market" where pretty much every fruit and vegetable imaginable is being sold by locals. This is Sri Lankan retail at its most concentrated!

This is not a market as such it's loads and loads of shops in narrow streets across from the columbo fort train station. The shops are located in areas eg textiles are in one street, electrical in another. If you are looking for something in particular to buy you will have to either get a good map or ask where it's sold as it is easy to lose your bearings. The best entry point is to find the clock tower and start from there. We wandered about for a couple of hours and although we didn't buy anything we had an enjoyable experience and felt quite safe. There are plenty of king coconut sellers and these cost 30 rupees each (about 15p) in the hotel they cost £1. they were very refreshing and necessary as it does get very hot. A couple of tips, carry plenty of small note denominations as things are cheap and the vendors often don't have change, we were staying in mount lavinia and it cost 10p to get the train into Colombo fort (much better value than a taxi or  tuktuk. And finally it gets very busy in the morning however this adds to the atmosphere. Well worth a look.

So, we visited this place on our way to having dinner. It seemed to be closing time. The salesmen were almost hostile in their effort to try and make us spend money on really bad fake clothes. I am not particularly cranky but when the logo on the pants says LEQ instead of LEE and the seem on the pocket is way off I do decline to buy. There were also some totally inappropriate behaviours from some people we passed who felt they had the right to feel what my behind felt like. As a twenty years old woman I did not feel safe there.

You would have to be a very committed shopper to get much from The Pettah. It is simply a busy local commercial district, full of bustling traders dealing in goods of every description. But there's not much for the tourist, I'm afraid. We made a particular effort to visit after recommendations in guide books and were disappointed. If you want to see any of the few historical buildings or visit Sea Street for the Gold Jewellery shops, take a 3 wheeler to get around - and hang on to your valuables if you venture on to the streets themselves.

We only managed to walk a couple blocks through the market before we decided that the goods, just everyday crap really, that were being offered were not worth risking our lives over. The streets or allyways were packed with people as well as cars and motorbikes. We found this to be a dangerous combination and experienced several near misses by having to jump out of the way of constant traffic. Proceed at your own risk.
Been there in a midday. Was fully packed and noisy. Very hot and dusty but loved the way as is. You can buy just about anything cheap stuff. Need to bargain. Loved it. It's Ceylon.

This was one of the highlights of my trip to Colombo. The market is incredible with so much to see. It is frenetic and noisy and full of people. Be careful of your belongings, keep your eyes open, take loads of photos and just enjoy the immersion in Colombo life!

Walking through the vicinity of market areas and station should be careful because of crowds of people around.  You could find different items in the market and stalls around. For expensive items you should check whether they were genuine or not.  A good experience to come here to see what the locals did in normal daily activities but recommend to do tourist shopping in the large shops in city centre.

Walk through it, dodging traffic, people and carts. Difficult to believe I am out of India in this market! Felt like the regular karolbagh market. Loud music, traffic jams, noise and jostling. The only difference being no creeps trying to feel you up! Pettah means - outside. When the Dutch fortified themselves, the outer zone was for the locals, the 'dark' ones. So all you meet in this market are the very local Sri Lankans. You can buy stuff if you are looking for inexpensive stuff. There is a long lane of muslim 'karigars' where you do notice some beautifully embroidered designs on clothes and purse. If you want a truly unique flavour of Colombo, do walk through this market. N one in my group wanted to do it. But I did it. Crossed it to go to the harbour. Had coconut water on the way. Liked it...

Pettah is one of the places to visit in Colombo if you are a visitor but for the locals most of them well it's a place they come at least one a week. It's a happening place during the day time but nothing much is there at night. it's like a huge open area shopping complex one thing it's open and lots of small building. From people on the pavement to small shops to three to four story building people can be seen doing business. what you want to buy they have it, like fruits, veggies to clothes, electronics, bags, CD's, shoes the list goes on and on.
