If you are a good bargainer you can shop what ever you want for a price you want. you will find good quality to cheep quality because most of the products are coming from China. a few problems are there like, roads are crowded and some times thieves are lurking among the crowds so protect your belongings. dusty and dirty so you have to be able to handle that and the sun. that said it's a nice experience to the adventurous soul.

Took me back in time when I entered this charming place. Spent hours window shopping and picking up odd trinkets, besides enjoyed some delightful bargains as well. The old facades and small shops selling a motley collection of useful things at amazingly low prices (bargaining welcome) were more enticing than the formal showrooms. A drink of the 'King' coconut was lingering for a long time and what a thirst quencher it was!!!!!!!!!!!

I often go to pettah to second cross street .This is the place to get any material threads zips binding etc  for overlocker threads these are less than 1 pound for 6 i.e 10000metres of thread!!  Other areas sell tea  spices cahew nuts etc  be prepared for this to be busy and noisy

This is not a convienient place for Tourists. Difficult park vehicles. You will have to walk in dust. If you are looking for Sarees this may be worth. Positive side is you can by many items very Cheap. You have to be careful on Duplicates.

While the Pettah market stocks pretty much everything you may need, as a tourist attraction i would say it is 'non-essential'. If you have been to a large market pretty much anywhere in the developing world, there is nothing new you will see in this place. Predictably, it is very very busy - some people will love this, others will hate it. On the other hand, most traders were friendly (I felt less hounded than I have done elsewhere) and the piles of fruit n veg were pretty.

You can say Pettah as the commercial center of Sri Lanka, where goods move in and out. If you like adventure walking then enter in to any of the cross streets. 2nd cross, 4th cross and so on. People used to fast walking here to do their business tasks, long carts filled with sacks of goods want to pass you with out minding you. Their tasks is to transport goods. Like wise small and large lorries to stay to pass by you in those narrow roads filled with shops and street vendors. Those roads are made with stones. Some time you will meet bullock carts too. Roads are filled muddy water during the rainy season. These roads are worth to look and not to walk as these belongs to those community. But when you come to the main street or Olcott Mawatha the scenery is far different. Main street is with lot of big clothing shops, electronic and electrical items selling shops along with small venders who used to sell lot of items. Best bargain here is leather products like shoes, small bags, belt and money purses. Heavy bargain is necessary with them, if you are a foreigner. You can jump in to the local Faluda shops for milk shake (Sri Lanka Style), Fresh fruit juices,  Indian style sweets or can drink your favorite chilled Cola. Noon time is hot with dust. it is better to visit by evening. Next to the Fort railway station you can find the newly organized floating market with a fine floating restaurant. Also you can visit the newly built "Gold center" in the heart of Pettah. Other attractions include Dutch Museum and the Wolvendaal Dutch Church and British era colonial buildings. If shopping is not on your list then a Sunday or a Poya day will be a good time to visit those buildings and to see those colonial streets.

Markets are always an interesting place to visit , we visited the Pettah Central Market on early July 2014.Located on Olcott Mawatha Road beside the Fort Railway Station. You could buy anything here from electronics, speakers , fans, of course all mainly made in China, fruits , snacks ,textile ,clothing ,drinks ,and souvenirs.Be careful with the price , because prices quite escalated a lot here ,especially for tourists. Beware of pickpockets, and on our experience , vendors here always talked to us offered us to pay their store a visit . Its quite a crowded market , except for the clothing market , saw just a few people here.Bought some clothes here with a good price , that's what our guide told us haha. This place is a good place to practice your bargaining skills.Hot , noisy,smelly and not the cleanest place to be. Worth a visit ,at least once
Local market with cheap products, Sales people will try to rip you off so please be ready for a bargain. Can be very crowded & noisy . this is the place if you are looking for cheap souvenirs

Avoid this place if you are a tourist and a non srilankan.  It's a local market where you get household stuff, groceries, vegetables etc. There are a few streets that sell footwear, mobile & other imported electronics but it's nothing special. It's untidy for a tourist but normal for a market standard. If you are speaking english, you will get ripped off. No benchmark for prices.

The district itself is just amazing to see.. Its very Asian : noisy, dirty and poor, but saying that i still loved it, cause its nothing you will experience in Europe. Plus you can buy absolutely everything there! They have seperate streets with specialised shops: with materials/textills, with spaces etc etc. Eventhough the heat is absurd I would still reccomend to do most of Sri Lankan shopping here. The prices are low (especially textills), selasman dont try to sell you everything they have in the shop (like in KANDY MARQUET), usually you have prices on the products so they cant cheat.

Pettah market is a place which every traveller visiting Colombo should not miss. There is nothing to buy for tourists as local people sell really every rubbish, but mummery of this place is a good experience.

An open-air market in the center of Colombo. You can buy various goods here, including local products and food. If you are person who likes walking in a hustle and bustle of whole streets dedicated to selling a particular type of merchandise, from local handicrafts to fresh produce. Definitely Pettah Market is for you. The markets will not be to everybody's taste, Pettah is a sensory overload and the sheer quantity of merchandise, and crowds of people, make it difficult to find good quality items. Bargaining is essential as foreigners tend to be overcharged. The quoted price will be at least double what locals would be expected to pay. Beware of pickpockets!

This is a local market... you can get everything here from plugs to sandals etc. But if you're looking for souvenirs, then this is not the place for you. You can get great souvenirs at any Odel. This market is more for buying random stuff like plugs, shoes, socks, belts etc.
We went for a quick walk there on our way to a mosque. This is a very crowded place with not many things to buy from there, especially if you are looking for souvenirs.

Spent over an hour walking through the Federation of Self Employees Market (FOSE) in Pettah. This consists, from what I could see, of three new hanger style buildings with open sides. One was chock-a-block with stalls selling all types of items. Clothes on hangers, in bales or simple in piles, shoes, sox, belts,  electronic goods, DVDs, tools, baubles, broaches, bangles and maybe even pearls. Pettah is where Sri Lankans come when they want to buy something at the cheapest possible price. It is the antithesis of Odels. Sellers and buyers haggle and the noise is constant yet not overpowering. Prices asked of foreigners are four to five time what the seller would normally expect so if you do not bargain you deserve to be ripped off. Do not expect quality. The second building housed sellers of every conceivable variety of fruits and vegetables. Heaps of green chilies, carrots, cauliflowers, gourds and aborigines of all shapes and sizes to name just a few, join with the mangos, pawpaws, wood apple, pineapples, passion fruits and other tropical fruits to present an artist’s palette  of color and textures to tempt the most discerning cook. There are also a few sellers of spices and even one or two selling dried salted fish which are a popular delicacy not just here in Sri Lanka but throughout the region.  I see that some reviewers have turned up their noses and that the vendor was burning incense sticks.  But lets face it, this market is a garden of roses compared to the salt and dry fish markets of the SE Asia. And speaking of smells, I found a fruit vendor selling Sri Lankan durians. I bought one and tried it on the spot but sad to say it was no match to its relatives grown in Vietnam, Thailand or Malaysia. The third building was not occupied when I visited. This is not one of the greatest markets I have visited but if you are in Pettah it is worth visiting.

This was the only place I had read, for bargain shopping in Colombo and I was keen to go there. It was quite a disappointment.The clothing was of a low quality and price quoted  was too high. It was just a waste of time as we were also stuck in the traffic. The only good thing was that I had the taste of my first King Coconut there.

Pettah is a typical market area - streets sell specific things so if you're after something specific do your research beforehand to know which street you need. It's busy, chaotic and a bit of an onslaught on your senses (watch out for the dried fish) but great if you like to immerse yourself. When you find what you want, haggle!

we were looking forward to a visit to this market thought a good afternoon out, but when we got there we had only been there about 10 mins and decided we wanted to leave, it was i can not say anymore a load of rubbish,it smelt, fumes etc, and we will never go there again.

Its not worth visiting.This is very very very crowded, hot and smelly.Crowd will try to Push you anywhere ;) so if you are going then you have to be very active and alert.Beware of pick -pockets Their are many small shop with lots of bargain you need to do, if you are planning to buy anything. For women travellers , its strict no-no and not a great shopping place. The only interesting site is Red-white Mosque.
This place is right near the bus station and a hive of activity. Sri Lanka at its greatest. Sweat will cover your body and your nose will get a proper workout!!! This is Sri Lanka

Pettah market is place that will give you sensory overload. Multiple little shops filled with so many different knick knacks. If you're a foreigner be prepared to bargain. Prices quoted are 4-5 times more than the actual price so don't be cheated. It definitely is a must visit if you're in Colombo.

Tourists are encouraged to visit this area as if it's an attraction. Basically it's nothing of the sort, it's a working Market for local people. We were the only non-locals in the area and although we didn't feel threatened in any way, we were clearly "getting under their feet". It is difficult to explain the noise, smells (mostly diesel fumes) and the sheer hustle and bustle of the area. The streets are quite narrow and tuk tusk, vans, barrows and lorries jostle for position while pedestrians look out for their life. Frankly we were glad to escape unscathed. One place worth visiting is the Dutch Museum on Prince Street. It's not very big or grand but has a certain charm and has an impressive collection of 17th century Dutch artefacts and furniture.

Started off on a gloomy day (if it was sunny it would not have been pleasant!) from Fort (Colombo 1) at 9.15am in a Budget Three Wheeler Taxi. Went direct to the wolfendhal church. Spent 1 hour or more there - listening to the caretaker (of 20 years) explain the intricacies of this ancient place. Took the same mode of transport to a dilapidated Museum with some old artifacts like road signs, lamps, steam rollers etc. Finally went to the dutch museum, pettah. The whole "tour" cost just over Rs.250 ($2.50)!   The dutch museum charges an entrance and camera fee.

The main thing about pettah is you can get anything you want for half of the price in stores (t-shirts to electrical items...etc),but you have to bargain for it otherwise the vendors will try to sell at high price. it’s always better to buy from the stores which has permanent location rather that the pedestrian sellers. Because some of them are not their if you go next day also their is no guaranty for any item you buy, that’s why it's half the price their. DO NOT go by vehicle their is no place to park. And you can visit lot's place if you go by foot. like the earlier comments beware of pickpocketers and do not eat from the carts

Pettah area in Colombo is easily reachable by 3-wheeler or walking from the Galle Face Green, and it's directly opposite the Fort Railway Station.  if you walk around a bit, you will come to the Prince street, and will easily see a very old building, the Dutch Museum.  Entry is about 500 rupees, and there are some faded exhibits, which are very tired.  Upstairs several rooms are furnished in beautiful old Dutch furniture. The building itself is the main attraction, though.  It was built some time in the 1600s and has a lovely courtyard and old colonial architecture.  What is interesting to me is the way the city has grown up around it and you can get a feel for what the area looked like 400 years ago, when the Dutch and the VOC were embroiled in the spice trade.

Pettah was amazing with all you could concieve being sold in this area. If you can think of it they will have it for sale. Want a green orangutang they have it, want fake anything they have it. There is also a dutch museum located in Pettah which is 'sort of' worth a visit, the villa itself is nicely decked out and the historical exhibits are a bit tired but still worth a look. Warning: Do not step in puddles in this district they could be highly toxic and acidic as I discovered with the utter destruction of the sole of my Blundstone boots.

Just east of Fort lies Pettah, the low end shopping district if Colombo. You will find everything from fruits to flowers, from gold to trinkets; from saris to t-shirts, from pots and pans to - simply think of it and its there. The overcrowded labyrinth of lanes and alleys is truly fascinating. Goods are stacked on the roadsides in heaps so the best way to move around is either on foot or on a rickshaw. If you want to find bargains like antiques and vibrant textile products this is the place. Just do not forget to haggle and bring the prices down. You can easily do your designer shopping of expensive ceramics and branded clothes in the posh areas of Colombo but this where you go to feel the pulse of the city and to witness its flurry and mayhem  The only warnings are- beware of the pickpockets and the creeps who pinch ladies’ behinds, never eat from the food carts and avoid gemstone peddlers  like plague.

Pettah market is easy to locate near the business centre area of the city (down the end past the "Inn on the Green" (amazing pub if you give it a try...bizarre to find attached to the gorgeous Galle Face Hotel (great for a massage and a wander around....lovely surroundings) you may want to brave it and hop on a 3 wheeler to get to the middle quickly. Pettah market is a very busy, smelly, hot, crowded, sticky place to be. BUT ITS AMAZING :-) its great fun, you can find some great bargains amoungst the best tack you have ever seen!! great for gifts, material, and necklaces etc. The shops are close together and in front of them there are stalls selling...well you name it :-) When you walk amoungst the stalls and shops you will be chatted to in the normal Lankan street vendor stylee... just smile and say no thank you, they will leave you alone. If they dont, just duck into the nearest shop where they would never dare to enter. It is normal in Sri Lanka for tourists to pay more than locals, you will find this often clearly displayed on the price boards of tourist hot spots such as the elephant orphange or other popular sites. this is deliberate, to enable more local people to use the attractions. Seeing as most Lankans live on very little, dont go overboard on the haggling but do ensure you get a bargain :-) if you buy from a street vendor.  shops should have prices labelled but if in doubt ask. If you have a native speaker with you its handy, as not all shops will speak english.  Often your hotel will be able to arrange for a young man to accompany you for a small cost (and a tip for the guy on the day) if you ask nicely. Hotels in Sri Lanka normally cannot do enough for you if you ask nicely and smile!! So head down to Pettah and get in the hustle and bustle, breathe in the scents and experience the sights and bargains!! But follow these rules: 1. Keep your possesions tucked away... you have only yourself to  blame if you get your pockets raided here... 2. Ladies, in Sri Lanka try to not go everywhere in hot pants and a vest top... most women there are quite modest and most never reveal cleavage... you stand out as a tourist there anyway and in a place like this you dont want to draw attention to yourself even more or you will be hassled by the street vendors more. 3. that said, keep your clothing cool and it will of course be hot and sticky and take some water with you as standard 4. try to take a guide if you can, but dont worry if you cant! you will manage! 5. enjoy! Hmmm... and if you have some extra pennies left over try the businessmans lunch at the Hilton...not as expensive as you would imagine!
